title: Central facial palsy with mild numbness NIHSS=2
content:

# BPH

# Dyslipidemia under Crestor use
# Hypertension

He has had right facial palsy with drooling and speak indistinctly since 10/20 morning when having breakfast. Assoicated symtpoms included mild numbness at right cheek. He denied fever, nausea or vomiting, blurred vision, slurred speech, head trauma, weakness or loss of conscious. 

LKNT: 10/20 08:00
[Patient baseline status] GCS456, pre-Stroke mRS:0
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert 
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
No rash or shingles noted 
facial palsy (+, right central palsy)
No tounge deviation

 - lower  (R/L: [5/5])
DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++

NIHSS = 000 001 0000 01000 = 2

# Central facial palsy, suspected left subcortical infarction

# Aspirin 3# STAT + 1# QD; Clopidogrel 4# STAT + 1# QD
# We have explained the clinical coarse to the patient and reminded the patient to warn about the red flag sign

title: Status epilepticus with GTCS
content:
This 40 y/o male has past history
# Hypertension without medical control
在家全身抽蓄雙眼上吊，發作10分鐘自行逐漸恢復，現意識清楚，第二次發作
第一次為今年8月在沖繩旅遊時
According to his family, he had convulsion over all extremities with bilateral eyes upper gazing for about 10 minutes today. 
Cold sweating was also noted. He denied any prior history of seizures, head trauma, stroke, or other neurological conditions.
His consciousness gradually improved on the ambulance with mild post-ictal confusion and nausea sensation, and had fully returned to baseline when he came to the ER.
This was his seond time seizure.
He denied any medication use. He had head trauma once at 2025/08 in Okinawa when he had his first time seizure.
He drinks a bottle of red wine per day for insomnia relief without remarkable increasing or decreasing amount recently. 
He denied febrile convulsion history, seizure-associated family history or past history.

According to his family, he experienced a convulsion involving all extremities with bilateral upward eye gazing for about 10 minutes when having dinner today. He denies any prior history of seizures, head trauma, stroke, or other neurological conditions. His consciousness gradually improved on the ambulance with mild post-ictal confusion and a sensation of nausea, and had fully returned to his baseline when he arrived at the ER.
This was his second time experiencing a seizure.
He denies fever, infection, stress or any current medication use. He reported a history of head trauma once in 2025/08 in Okinawa, which was when he had his first seizure.
He drinks a bottle of red wine per day for insomnia relief, with no remarkable recent increase or decrease in the amount.
He denies a history of febrile convulsions, a family history of seizures, or any other pertinent past medical history.

Lab data showed Ammonia 99, GOT(AST) 278, Bilirubin T 1.3, GPT(ALT) 166, Lipase 83, WBC 11.86
Brain CT scan: no ICH or remarkable lesion noted

[NE]
Consciousness:E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM:full,pupil(R/L:2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
Motor: upper (R/L:5/5),lower (R/L:5/5)
DTR: L4(R/L):++/++
no dysarthria, no dysphagia,
no diplopia, no hearing impairment,no tinnitus 

Impression:
# Recurrent convulsive status epilepticus, secondary to suspected hyperammonemia or hepatic dysfunction
# Acute hepatocellular Injury, probably alcohol-related

Suggestion:
# Keppra 1000mg STAT + 500mg Q12H IVD
# We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, and reminded them about the red flag sign.
# Admission (#11294)

title: TIA

He also mentioned intermitent tension headache within one week. The headache ocurred once a day, with duration of 20-30 minutes, and mainly during his sleeping time. He denied nausea or vomiting, visual or hearing abnormalities.

title: Herpes zoster
content:

He had frequent flu in recent months with more stressed work.
He had right headache for 3 days and vesicle over right forehead since yesteray.

Herpes zoster over right CNV1 with right blepharoconjunctivitis

title: Left VN
content:

She had unsteady gait without deviation to specific side. She had chronic headache problem but totally improved around 5 years ago. She denied blurred vision, hearing impairment, slurred speech, LOC, fever or recent head truama.

no dysarthria, no dysphagia, no facial palsy, no diplopia, no hearing impairment, no tinnitus, no meningeal signs, no neck stiffness

A 65 y/o male has past history of Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Tardive Dyskinesia, and Parkinson's Disease.
 * History: He underwent Gamma Knife radiosurgery at our hospital in November for severe left leg resting tremor and dyskinesia (abnormal foot inversion affecting gait).
 * HPI: He has been under regular Madopa 125mg control with stable status until 12/14 morning.
 * Symptoms: He presented with worsening resting tremor. The tremor progressed from the left leg to involve the right leg, bilateral hands, and body (legs > hands/body).
 * Alleviating factors: The patient reported that taking an additional 0.5 tablet of Madopa alleviated the symptoms.
 * Denials: He denied fever, recent head trauma, nausea or vomiting, headache, limb weakness, numbness, diarrhea, constipation, or new medication use.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
 * Consciousness: E4V5M6, clear.
 * Cranial Nerves:
   * EOM: Full.
   * Facial palsy: (-).
   * Tongue: Mild tremor (+), no deviation.
 * Motor: upper (R/L: [5/5]), lower (R/L: [5/5]).
 * Tremor: Resting tremor noted over bilateral legs and hands.
 * Tone: No rigidity or spasticity. No active dyskinesia observed.
 * DTR: L4(R/L): [++/++].
 * Babinski sign: R/L: [down/down].
Workup:
 * Brain CT and Lab data were arranged to rule out intracranial hemorrhage, infection, or electrolyte/metabolic imbalance.
Impression:
Parkinson's disease with acute worsening of resting tremor.
Rule out metabolic encephalopathy or electrolyte imbalance.
Suggestion:
Wait for Lab and CT results to exclude acute medical causes (infection/ICH/metabolic).
If acute medical causes are excluded, consider adjustment of anti-Parkinson agents.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Suggest Neurology OPD follow up.
